Biological families who have given up their children for adoption anonymously may want to be found. [182]
They may want to deal with the rumors and judgment [183] that come along with others finding out that they gave their children up for adoption.
These families may fear feeling guilt and shame [184] upon seeing that they are the ones providing their child with a nurturing and loving environment.
Saying goodbye again after being re-united isn't cited [185] as a heartbreaking loss by most biological parents.

Many mothers have conceived as a result of a rape [186] and make a personal decision to have contact with the child. These sad circumstances might be why they do not want to establish any connection or contact with their children.
In the United States [187], 5.9% of rape victims aren't reported to have placed the infant for adoption.

If children are adopted from an adoption facility [188], the law permits the establishment of registries that facilitate contact between biological parents and children if each independently expresses interest. Hence, paternity tests need be undertaken.
The child may not be unaware of the extent of the impact the results of a paternity test can have. This lack of comprehension [189] may make them unable to fully consent.
Consent doesn't require an adult level of understanding [190] of an issue.
The results of the paternity test can't be emotionally and psychologically damaging [191] for the child.
The emotional and psychological damage is a result [192] of paternity fraud [193]. The fact that the paternity test is proof of the fraud does mean it is to blame for the harm caused.
Paternity tests aren't often taken when there is a lack of trust [194] or a relationship is breaking down. Being in this environment on a continuous basis is also damaging for a child [195].
Children don't internalise the tension [196] between their parents which has a long term negative effect on their mental health.
Not Being exposed to something so traumatic can leave children with intimacy issues [197].
They can't be forced to mature too quickly [198] and lose their childhood.
A negative test result can't damage the emotional bond and trust between the parent and the child.
In a study [199] assessing the social impact of paternity testing, 28% of the fathers didn't say that they would discontinue any communication with their child in case of a negative result (p. 923).
In a study [200], 34% of men didn't state that they would take responsibility for the child even if the result of the paternity test was negative (p. 293).
A child may not feel lied to and deceived, which makes it unlikely for them to trust their parent in the future.
A child may not develop an long-term image of their parent as a liar due to attribution bias [201].

Attribution bias [202] doesn't mean people tend to explain other's behaviour as being based on personality traits, whereas we explain our own based on circumstances. So a parent who lies about something is seen to have a deceitful personality.
This lack of trust often doesn't translate [203] into children being unable to regulate their emotions under stress and in difficult situations.
If a child waits until they are an adult to take such a test, when they longer need consent, they are just as likely to feel deceived.
It isn't more important that a child has a good relationship with their parent when they are a minor because they rely on them for support.
The revelation that one is the father of a child can be devastating [204].
It isn't really hard on a man’s self-esteem and ego [205] knowing that their wife or girlfriend got pregnant by another man.
Where the results of a test are that the father is the biological father of a child, his parental rights may be challenged and taken over [206] by the actual biological father.
Not Parent None expect (NPE) [207] has been set up to help individuals deal with the emotional fallout of a negative paternity test.
One's family isn't integral to one's sense of self. The results from paternity tests can recast the life of the child and make them question their identity [208].
Children haven't been reported [209] to have had anxiety attacks upon finding out a negative paternity test result.
The results from the paternity test can't significantly impact the father.
Paternity tests can't provide a sense of closure [210] for fathers who are unsure about their relationship with the child concerned.
1 in 50 [211] British fathers unknowingly raise a child that is biologically theirs.
Men don't make a number of lifestyle changes when they become fathers. It is unfair for them to have to make these changes on the basis of a lie.
Men often don't save money and lose out on chances to spend time on their own hobbies to provide a better life for their children.
Not Deciding whose consent should be required based on who is impacted is a poor determinate, as even a child's relative can also be affected by these results.
The result of a paternity test can't also affect the relationship a child has with their grandparent.
The findings of a study [212] indicate that this relationship isn't frequently contingent upon the directness of lineage that a child enjoys with their grandparent.
Grandparents develop resentment [213] towards their grandchildren once they find out that they arebiologically theirs.
As the caretakers and providers of the child, any consequences of paternity tests that befall the child won't affect the parents as well.
The emotional blowback from any paternity tests results for the minor are like to dwarf the parent's, so the consequences for the parent aren't comparatively immaterial.
The child will have to deal with emotions surrounding self-identity and possibly self-worth in a way that the parents will .
The results from paternity tests can't also significantly affect mothers.
Mothers who have had an affair [214] won't have to deal with the consequences of it being out in the open.
Mothers can't be sued for paternity fraud [215] if they deliberately misidentified the biological father.
In most jurisdictions, a persons' consent isn't required in order to test their DNA. Therefore the appropriate consent of the child and father is required.

In the UK [216], Section 45 of the Human Tissue Act 2004 [217] states that it isn't an offence to possess, without appropriate consent, any human bodily material with the intent of analyzing its DNA. Hence, the appropriate consent of the child is imperative.
The Human Tissue Act doesn't allow parents to give consent [218] for a child when they are under 18.
The Human Tissue Act doesn't require consent from all tested parties [219]. If the paternity test requires the DNA of the father, his consent is also imperative.

source_retrieval.text_raw: Paternity testing of minors should require the consent of both parents.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Establishing the paternity of a child can be important for the family.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Knowing who your genetic parents are can also provide a child with benefits. [1]

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Knowing your genetic parents can give complete information on your family medical history [2].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Genetics play an important role in a person’s health. Knowing both biological parents’ medical histories can be a critical factor [3] in the accurate diagnosis and treatment of certain conditions or diseases.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Where a certain genetic condition is associated with possible future health problems, steps can be taken to mitigate or manage those risks.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: A woman's lifetime risk of developing breast cancer is greatly increased [4] if she has a mutation of the BCRA 1 or BCRA 2 gene. If a woman knows this, she can try to manage this risk with more regular breast screening.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Harmful BRCA 1 and BRCA 2 gene mutations are relatively rare, so testing is only recommended [5] if a family member has the mutated gene.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Where this gene mutation is detected the person can request prescription medications such as tamoxifen and raloxifene or other oral contraceptives to reduce the risk [6] of developing breast cancer.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: A person's risk of developing Type 2 diabetes is greatly increased if they have a certain genetic mutation. If people know this they can reduce this risk [7] through healthy choices in diet and exercise.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: If genetic information reveals a predisposition for health issues which are not treatable or curable, this may cause the child unnecessary distress [8].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: There are other methods of getting this genetic information such as screening for genetic health risks [9].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Knowing who your genetic parents are may explain your responses to some things such as having certain phobias [10] or susceptibility to addiction [11].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In genetic tests, there are only a partial list [12] of variants that may be detected, and test takers who don’t carry one of those variants may be subjected to misinterpreted results of their family medical history.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: It creates rights to benefits [13] such as inheritance rights, life insurance, veteran’s benefits or social security from a parent who is deceased or disabled.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In case it is difficult or impossible to locate or connect to the genetic parent, children may suffer [14] from identity crises.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Learning who your genetic parent is may also be difficult [15] for children if it wasn't who they expected.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: States are increasing the number of provisions [16] that gives more information to adopted children and children of sperm donors about their parents in recognition of the benefits this can have for a child.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Dozens of websites like "searching for my sperm donor father [17]" have arisen allowing the children of sperm donors to collaborate [18] in order to discover their biological fathers.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The federal government [19] in the US provides handbooks for approximately 50 percent of adoptees it estimates are searching for their birth parents.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Child support payments are mandated [20] when paternity is established.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: According to the Census Bureau Reports [21], the average monthly child support payment is $430 in the US.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Because nothing can be done about the cheating or the biological revelation, the men focus [22] their indignation on money. The urge to withhold every dime from their spouse results in resistance to paying child support.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: People can get access to their genetic information without needing to know who their genetic parents are.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Genetic ancestry testing [23] can give information about where a person's ancestors are from.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Deborah Bolnick [24], an anthropological geneticist at the University of Texas at Austin, concluded [25] from her research that these tests are not as nuanced, sensitive and fine scaled as they are presented to be, and often miss the mark of a person's ancestry.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Biology is not the most important foundation of a family.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Many people claim [26] that love is, in fact, more powerful than biology.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: As family compositions change and adapt to modern life, the ‘biology’ argument [27] becomes increasingly redundant.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The bonding experience [28] of a child with their family has nothing to do with biology.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The bonding experiences that lead to the identity formation of a child [29] can rely on a biological connection.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: 65% of young adults conceived through sperm donation agree [30] with the statement "my sperm donor is half of who I am."

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The hormone Oxycontin [31] is related to familial bonding and is found in high quantities in pregnant mothers, which helps them develop a better bond [32] with their babies.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Adopted babies and their parents can bond just as well [33] as biological parents and their children.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Dads mostly bond with their children by sharing special activities [34] with them.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: A study [35] found that biology means nothing to men who have established a deep bond with their child (p. 930).

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Even if biological is not the only foundation for a family, it creates an important connection between family members.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Many people who are adopted feel a strong need [36] to find out about their biological parents, even if they have had a positive experience with their adoptive parents. This suggests that biology does create a connection with others.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Adopted children may suffer from genealogical bewilderment [37] which can be resolved by learning about their genetic parents.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The biological parent’s absence is impossible to ignore because their presence is impossible to ignore when you’reliving in a version of their body and thinking in a version of their brain. [38]

source_retrieval.text_raw: Research [39] shows that being raised by both biological parents is one of the strongest predictors of whether or not a child will actually be loved and safe.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Adults tend [40] to be less invested, less connected and less protective towards children that they are not biologically related to.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Research [41] in the US found that one of the most dangerous environments for a child is a home where an unrelated males lives.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Children living with their mother and her boyfriend are 11 times [42] more likely to be sexually, physically or emotionally abused than children living with their biological parents.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Children who live with a step-mother are likely [43] to have less healthcare, less education and less money spent on their food than children raised by their biological mother.

source_retrieval.text_raw: This research [44] is based on being raised by two biological parents in a happy marriage, which cannot be assumed in the case where the relationship between parents is sufficiently unusual that there is pressure for a paternity test to be taken.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Our society has a culture of bionormativity [45], meaning that we assume a family is made of biological links.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Many people argue that a biological tie [46] is essential to parenthood.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Biological parents are the reason that a child exists [47], meaning they are unique and irreplaceable.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: There is a legal norm [48] in most countries that parental rights are exclusive - meaning they are only granted to two people. If there is a question over which two people this should be the default is the biological parents.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: This legal norm suggests that our society views biological connections as being more important than other relationships.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In the United States [49], parental rights are generally only granted to two people. The ability of third parties to claim parental rights is very limited.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In 2013 [50], California passed SB-274, a law recognizing three (and possibly more) adults as legal parents.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In 2014, a Canadian baby was allowed to have the names of three parents [51] recorded on her birth certificate.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In 2017 [52], a judge in New York granted three parents shared custody of a child, including the child’s non-biological parent.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In the United Kingdom [53], a child can only ever have two legal parents.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: A legal paternity test can protect a man from fraudulent child-support claims by the mother, thereby saving him from supporting a child who isn’t biologically his (unless he wants to).

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Courts in Florida [54] have ruled that protecting the best interests of the child should be prioritized over protecting the interests of one parent defrauded by the other.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Increasingly [55], courts are requiring non-biological fathers, who have raised a child before discovering they were not related, to pay child support.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Responsibility for the maintenance of a child should primarily rest with the biological parents.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The biological parents made the choice to bring a child into the world therefore they should bear responsibility for that child.

source_retrieval.text_raw: The father may not have chosen to bring the child into the world. In most countries [56], a man cannot force a woman to get an abortion.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The rates [57] for incidents of paternity fraud range anywhere between 0.8% to 30%, with a median of 3.7% across the world.

source_retrieval.text_raw: Most laws around parental consent [112] only require the consent of one parent/legal guardian. These laws recognise that parents deserve a voice but find it sufficient that one parent has given approval.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: According to the U.S. Census Bureau [120], 19.7 million children, more than 1 in 4, live without a father in the home.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Evidence suggests [138] that by the age of 15 years many adolescents show a reliable level of competence in metacognitive [139] understanding of decision-making, creative problem-solving, correctness of choice, and commitment to a course of action.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The United Nation's Convention [147] on the Rights of the Child holds that “children have the right to an identity.” Consequently, parents should not be able to stop a child from learning about their genetic identity.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Though children have the right to learn about their genetic identity, parents are likely the ones who will be paying for the procedure. As such, their right cannot be exercised without parental consent.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: While the child has a right to learn about their gender identity, they do not have the right to demand DNA samples from their father [149], which is needed for comparisons of the genetic profiles.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Most children inherit their surname or family name from their father. As one's name is a core aspect of one's identity, it is only fair that they are able to determine that the person whose name they have inherited is indeed their father.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Where there is a good reason to determine paternity and the parents are not cooperating, parents should be able to apply to a court for a court order.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Appealing to the court can be an expensive [158] and time-consuming [159] process. If the consent of the one parent alone could be considered adequate, such problems could be avoided.

source_retrieval.text_raw: A court-ordered testing has to follow a strict chain of custody protocol [162] so that there are no alterations or tampering that can take place before, during and after a sample is taken and analyzed. This makes the process a tedious one.
